subsection.title: Products of Powers
subsection.p: Suppose we would like to multiply two powers together. For instance, consider the product (x^3)(x^4), which can be written as (x^3)(x^4)=xxx \cdot xxxx = x^7 because x occurs as a factor 7 times. We see that the number of x's in the product is the sum of the number of x's in each factor.

On the other hand, if we'd like to multiply x^3 times y^4, we cannot simplify the product because the two powers do not have the same base. (x^3)(y^4)=xxx \cdot yyyy = x^3y^4 These observations illustrate the following rule.

assemblage.title: First Law of Exponents
assemblage.p: To multiply two powers with the same base, we add the exponents and leave the base unchanged. In symbols, \blert{a^m \cdot a^n = a^{m+n}}

statement.p:
In each product below, we keep the same base and add the exponents.
x^2 \cdot x^6 = x^8
5^2 \cdot 5^5 = 5^8

ol.label: a
ol.li: How do we simplify the product of two powers with the same base?
How do we simplify the product of two powers with different bases?

ol.label: a
ol.li: We add the exponents and leave the base unchanged.

subsection.title: Products of Monomials
subsection.p: We can use the first law of exponents to multiply two monomials together.

solution.p: We rearrange the factors to group together the numerical coefficients and the powers of each base. (2x^2y)(5x^4y^3) = (2)(5)~x^2x^4~yy^3 We multiply the coefficients together, and use the first law of exponents to find the products of the variable factors. (2)(5)~x^2x^4~yy^3 = 10x^6y^4

statement.p: Which law of algebra allows us to rearrange the factors in a product?

subsection.title: Multiplying by a Monomial
subsection.p: To multiply a polynomial by a monomial, we use the distributive law.

solution.p: We apply the distributive law to multiply each term of the polynomial by the monomial -3xy^2. -3xy^2(4x^2-2xy+2) \amp = -3xy^2(4x^2)-3xy^2(-2xy)-3xy^2(2) \amp = -3 \cdot 4 \cdot x \cdot x^2 \cdot y^2 -3(-2) \cdot x \cdot x \cdot y^2 \cdot y-3 \cdot 2 \cdot xy^2 \amp = -12x^3y^2+6x^2y^3-6xy^2 To simplify each term, we group together the coefficients and powers with the same base.

statement.p: Which algebraic law do we use when we multiply a polynomial by a monomial?

subsection.title: Products of Polynomials
subsection.p: In Chapter 5 we found the product of two binomials using the "FOIL" method, a special case of the distributive law. We can also use the distributive law to help us compute products of two or more polynomials.

solution.p: We multiply each term of the first polynomial by each term of the second polynomial. This involves six multiplications: We first multiply each term of the trinomial by 2x, then multiply each term by -1. (\blert{2x}\alert{-1})(3x^2-x+2) \amp = \blert{2x}(3x^2)+\blert{2x}(-x)+\blert{2x}(2)\alert{-1}(3x^2)\alert{-1}(-x)\alert{-1}(2) \amp = 6x^3-2x^2+4x-3x^2+x-2 ~~~~~~ \blert{\text{Combine like terms.}} \amp = 6x^3-5x^2+5x-2

statement.p: How many terms are there in the product of two trinomials?

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: f a product contains both polynomial and monomial factors, it is a good idea to multiply the polynomial factors together first, and save the monomial factor for last.

solution.p: We begin by multiplying the binomial factors, (x+2)(3x-5). 2x[\blert{(x+2)(3x-5)}] \amp = 2x[\blert{3x^2-5x+6x-10}] \amp = 2x(3x^2+x-10) Next we use the distributive law to multiply the result by 2x. 2x(3x^2+x-10) = 6x^3+2x^2-20x

statement.p: To compute the product 3a(a+6)(4a-1), which factors should we multiply first?

subsection.p: In a product of three or more polynomials, we start by multiplying together any two of the three factors.

solution.p: We begin by multiplying together the last two binomials, (a+2)(2a-3). (3a-1)[\blert{(a+2)(2a-3)}] \amp = (3a-1)[\blert{2a^2-3a+4a-6}] \amp = (3a-1)(2a^2+a-6) Now we use the distributive law to multiply each term of the trinomial by each term of the binomial, as shown in Example 4. (3a-1)(2a^2+a-6) \amp = 6a^3+3a^2-18a-2a^2-a+6~~~~ \blert{\text{Combine like terms.}} \amp = 6a^3+a^2-19a+6
